review_title: It pretty nice depends on the family

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY

review_title: The needs of employees aren’t considered.
job_title: Care Manager in Buffalo, NY
pros: It’s an office job, and when you’re able to actually get something through the red tape, it can be satisfying.
cons: The needs of their employees are not a concern of leadership. They are inflexible when it comes to working from home when there are established family needs such as family member illness or personal illness. They offer 15 PTO days per year, and when you need to take off sick, they call it “Emergency PTO” and it counts against you in your annual review. I worked in the Buffalo office, which is micromanaged by upper leadership in NYC. The Executive Director is not open to any criticism and will push people out that rock the boat. When COVID hit, they set up work from home accommodations for everyone as needed, but brought everyone back into the office as quickly as possible. They have had numerous COVID outbreaks in the office as a result as people are no longer allowed to work from home as needed, and are afraid of getting in trouble for taking emergency PTO.

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: The work was Meaningful and fulfilling
cons: Very busy and High caseload

job_title: HCBS Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Easy work life good schedule one day remote work life
cons: Training is horrible lack of management

job_title: Quality Assurance in New York, NY
pros: Friendly internal staff great office building
cons: Management was a mess. Pay is extremely low

review_title: They Need to Build Their Management Team From Scratch
job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros:
- Great Coworkers

job_title: Care Manager in New York, NY
pros:
I truly enjoyed working here as a case manager in the Health Homes department. I learned so much within my time here, helped a lot of families and made good friends. My supervisors were very patient, knowledgeable and did not make me feel less than. Coworkers are extremely helpful. CEO is very knowledgeable and passionate about this work. This is a great entry level job with a great benefits package.

I enjoyed being in the field before COVID. It allowed me to provide hands on work to my clients. It was nice to travel all throughout New York. 

The families we serve are very nice people and very grateful for our services.

I am a person of color and did not feel discriminated against whatsoever so this is a place where everyone is welcomed.

I love skip and will cherish my experience here forever.❤️
cons: Well living in NYC is rather expensive so we could get paid a bit more but other than that I see no cons, I truly enjoyed working here. This is not a place where people work just to get a pay check, everyone here truly cares about the families they serve.

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: The people are nice and the semi flexible hours works with you.
cons: It can get passive aggressively divided in office.

job_title: Community Habilitation Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Hands off approach to management
cons: Management is never on the same page and there is a lack of communication

review_title: Small with good benefits but concerned with bottom line
job_title: Case Manager in Rochester, NY
pros:
Small Case Load
Flexible hours
Good Benefits
cons:
Nitpick work 
Don't see the forest for the trees in terms of family needs being unique

job_title: Caseworker in New York, NY
pros: flex hours and a nice location in chelsea
cons: poor pay and serious micromanagement

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros:
The families and individuals that you will assist in getting services.  I always feel appreciated and I am constantly being thanked for my hard work. 
Having an hour and a half window to get to work.
Open door policy with any level of staff (no matter the person or department if you have a question someone will stop to answer you)
A great place to "START" a career; if you are right out of college start at SKIP of New York.
The day/week goes by quickly due to all the work.
cons:
No non-profit agency will pay great salaries however there is a huge discrepancy with positions, work-loads, and salaries at SKIP. Again my personal observance were certain positions were not needed and others that were extremely important were overlooked.
The commute is not easy (on 26th St. between 11th and 12th)
The use of DISPO - tracking all work to keep account of productivity adds to the mounting work you have to do. 
Only 37.50 hours not 40; benefits not so great.

job_title: Community Habilitation Instructor in New York, NY
pros:
-minimal admin work
- focus is on the clients
- provides raises with time
cons: - They limit hours to just 10 a week, though the state allows for more.

job_title: Service Coordinator in Buffalo, NY
pros: Sadly I can't think of any pros to this job.  Perhaps the fact that they seemed desperate to hire someone may help someone fresh out of college get some experience in this field.
cons: This honesly was the worst job I've ever had.  The micromanaging that goes on is not only unneccessary but completely ridiculous.  As an employee you must be accountable by logging into a computer system for every 10 minutes of your time!!  This was the stupidest, most crazy thing I've seen while on a job site!  In addition supervisory staff would watch over your shoulder constantly which I found so frustraing and degrading.  This company does not seem to releazie that they have ADULTS working for them and not children!  There is honeslty not even enough work to do at times and heaven forbid the company would allow you to leave early on a holiday or a Friday.   I had almost all of the families I worked with tell me that I was the tenth SKIP employee they had in a very short amount of time which makes perfect sense when I consider the poor treatment you are given as a staff member.  Honestly it really was the worst job I ever had.  By the way I worked in the Buffalo office.

job_title: Quality Assurance in New York, NY
pros:
-Whatever good there were, was slowly torn away from the employees.
-You don't pay for insurance directly out of your check but you pay a lot in co pays.
-Good entry level job, get your experience and build your resume.
cons:
-No ice machine (4 ice trays, over 100 employees) (oh and pack your own coffee too)
-HR Allows harassment of employees while sweeping incidents under the rug.
-More focus on billing than quality output of work.
-No attempt to send condolences (cards/flowers) to families of deceased clients.
-Upper management puts an extreme amount of pressure on supervisors, which leads to them pressuring case managers, leaving them overwhelmed and disgruntled. 
-LOW LOW LOW PAY on all levels
-Pay discrepancies, where individuals in promoted positions and signing off on the case managers work were making less than the actual case managers. (Given the reason that some departments weren't revenue generating departments)
-Upper management never keeps staff abreast of upcoming changes. You will learn about things when things hit the fan, with no advance warning.
-Forget about having your own voice, you will get called into the office and scrutinized 
-They will pile on as much work as they can on you with no pay increase. As per the executive director, "people must learn when to say no"
-When it comes to SKIP, "Just say no"

review_title: How long can this agency survive?
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Mission of agency to assist families with sick and disabled children is clear and strongly communicated
Regular training sessions are scheduled that include external presenters. These sessions are an opportunity for novice staff to learn about benefits and services available to the families they are assisting
cons:
Supervisors too often do not have the skills they need to lead a group nor do they seem to have the knowledge required to impart to novice staff
New case managers are assigned caseloads so small it is impossible for them to meet the billing standards expected and faulted for lack of productivity 
Excessive staff turnover has resulted in poor continuity of services to families and continuing stress for supervisors who must constantly train new staff and carry caseloads until staff is replaced
Board of Directors apparently is unconcerned about the decline in the reputation of the agency and has been unconcerned as the executive director hired her son in an unnecessary position as a videographer and paying him a salary twice that of the average caseworker.

job_title: Service Coordinator in Buffalo, NY
pros: Sadly I can't think of any...honestly.
cons:
You are constantly micro managed.
You have to bill for EVERYTHING that you do and keep track of every ten minutes you work by logging it into a computer.  I found this absolutely ridiculous.  Made me feel like a child even though I'm a grown adult with a mortgage, kids, experience and a college education.  
The pay is awful.
Managment could care less about you.
No perks available to make up for the low wages.  Most of the girls in the office (I worked at the Buffalo Office) are Mom's with children at home.  I honestly felt like this job could be done on a part time basis or even some of it at home but the only thing managment wants to see is you glued to the desk for 8 hours straight with basically NOTHING to do at times.  Families constantly told me how many S.C.'s they had went through and it took me all of a week to realize why.  Even when you've have a simple conversation at your desk (during a down time when you didn't have much to do) you would get a look from managment.

job_title: Service Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great learning experience. Wonderful view, clean and nice kitchen area.
cons: Too many under qualified supervisors and too much micro management. The administrative staff and director work really hard to pick at everything.  Very stressful environment due to harassment by upper staff. Only 30 mins to eat and not a min over. You have no voice , upper staff only listen to supervisors and everything you do or say gets turned around.  Not allowed to ask other co workers questions at all.  Very controlling place to the point of crazy. This agency could be way more but egos and control freaks hinder your growth and potential and take away from the services for the consumers.

job_title: Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: SKIP of New York is by far the hardest working case management agency across the state of NY. The agency will never turn down a family that is in need of services. SKIP is not the type to take no for an answer and will stop at nothing to provide necessary services to the individuals they serve. The fact that the founding members who started SKIP over 30 ago are here everyday fighting for the families everyday is a testament to the agency's dedication and overall mission. The jobs done at SKIP are by no means easy however seeing the children at home thriving, going to school, parents going to work and family units staying together makes the job all worth it. This is the place you want to be to learn a lot about real life and what real life families go through on a daily basis.
cons: Every experience in life is what the person makes of it.

review_title: Case Manager / Service Coordinator (Home Care) in New York, N.Y.
job_title: Case Manager/Service Coordinator (Home Care) in New York, NY
pros:
- Laidback work environment as far as taking breaks, giving you room to handle business matters, and flexible schedule (can come into work anytime between 8am to 930am all day, every week.
- You also get to travel and see your clients and get out of the mudance office scenary
cons:
- Low salary to start 
- Can't work over-time to make extra money
- Short lunch period (30 minutes) which is not enough time to go outside and get lunch because there are no close by restaurants to eat at.
- A big workload which is not rewarded enough thru the salary

job_title: Administrative in Buffalo, NY
pros: The upside is the company does great things with good purpose. Coworkers are generally friendly and try to be helpful.
cons: Double standards exist to the extreme at this company at the managerial/supervisor level and everyone else in regards to policy. Certain managers are extremely poor communicators. I directed confronted my boss about my coworkers total lack of ability and work ethic and they basically gave me every excuse and lied to my face. They made no attempts to work with said employee or anything constructive, while at other times questioning perfectly capable people who are doing a great job. Everyone is overloaded due to the non profit nature of the company, but little is done about it. Managers are very unprofessional and complain openly to employees about other employees, which I think is very inappropriate. Managers also swear and yell and are not good under pressure.

job_title: Habilitation Specialist in New York, NY
pros: great families to work with, a few days for paid sick leave, small raise every year
cons: low pay, too much paperwork/reports; I felt it was more about paperwork then the kids; no one seemed to stay working there above me/case workers kept changing

job_title: Service Coordinator in Rochester, NY
pros: Free health insurance, families are great, job offers great experience, mission of company is awesome.
cons: Where do I start, the director of the company along with HR show very little interest in the well-being of their employees. Office supervisor does not have the educational credentials to do the job she has. Other supervisors are lazy and unwilling to assist staff. The work environment is completely unprofessional. Horrible mileage reimbursement. HR loves to sweep incidents under the rug and there is rarely any follow up. If complaints are ever made be sure management will turn it into an issue with staff and not supervisors. Management is unethical and dishonest about business practices. There are too many personal relationships within the office that affect the professional relationship. Overall SKIP is just plain shady.

job_title: Service Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Excellent view of the water, the building that it is in has ton of really great sample trucks and on thursdays the dumpling truck is outside yay
cons: the management is rude and unprofessional, they do not value the works and that is why the turn over will continue to be so high... there are families who have had 6 case managers in 1 year thats crazy! SKIP does not pay what their employees are worth...there are people there who a working thier and have to work retail jobs just so that they could support themselves.... when you have to do your full time job, deal with bull from supervisors, directors etc you shouldnt have to go to a second job

job_title: Service Coordinator in New York, NY
pros:
Great camaraderie among service coordinators
Opportunity to learn about a lot of things related to special needs even starting with no knowledge base 
Home visit traveling gets you out of the office for some variety in your day
cons:
Small micromanaging administrative staff
Few informal perks 
Low salary for the amount of work you do
Some contention among workers due to favoritism by administrative staff

job_title: Habilitation Specialist in New York, NY
pros: Skip offers amazing services to families with a disabled person. Also the hiring process is fairly easy. The interview is a breeze. Especially if you are refered by a current employee consider yourself hired.
cons: I decline to comment due to present employment status. I will say that they certainly have their fair share of cons.

review_title: Not the most organized But the most Loving
job_title: Case Manager in Rochester, NY
pros: The supervisor is like a super star... she is a role model and the best boss (and parent) in the world... she inspires that office and works harder then anyone in the world... and she makes sure that the employees get great treatment/benefits for the hard work. Also seeing the kids go through what they deal with and they handle it like a boss and they just want to be happy it opens your eyes up to life in a new way.
cons: The pay should be more it’s hard work

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Focused mission, good camaraderie and a great sense of humor from coworkers, transparency from deputy director and HR regarding why decisions are made, desire from the top of the organization to help families and individuals in numerous capacities, desire and willingness to promote from within and support for professional development.
cons: High turnover at direct care level, but this is common for the human services field. Wish agency had a tuition reimbursement program of some sort.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros:
Mission driven culture is promoted. When I first started at Skip I was pleasantly surprised by the involvment of higher managmnet in the care and service they offer to children and their families. 
You would learn a lot at skip if you are new to non profit organizations.
cons: Nothing you would not find in other work places, but specific to non profit organizations you are overworked and underpaid, ....

job_title: Case Manager in Rochester, NY
pros: There was free health insurance. If I could give negative stars I would.  The first day I arrived I knew I made a mistake. Working there was the worst experience ever! I become nauseous and think I have PTSD from working there. They clock your every move. Totalitarianism at its finest.
cons:
micro management
organization does not trust employees
high turn over rate
staff does not care about employees
low pay for the amount of work and stress
had to share one "internet computer" with the office because staff was not trusted to be on the internet at their desk. When we were trusted, almost every work related site was blocked

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: You get to make a real difference in the lives of families with sick and disabled kids.  I have accumulated countless unforgettable memories from the many years I worked at SKIP. My favorite thing about the job is that you get to fight the bad guys on behalf of the kids and their overwhelmed  families and you usually get to win. An amazing learning experience that continues over time.  Flexible work schedule. Full benefits. A great opportunity  for anyone who wants to advocate for sick kids and isnt afraid of hard work.
cons: As with any non-profit agency, salaries are very low when compared with similar positions and similar educational requirements in for profit companies.  If you want to get rich, you wont do that at SKIP...try being an investment banker or a rock star instead. A caring person can experience a lot of emotional stress from working with such sick children and overwhelmed families over time. It is also easy to get caught up in a family's distress and it takes experience to learn to balance time spent working with personal life and family.

review_title: don't work here unless you're desperate.
job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: the families on my caseload were great. developing relationships with them and helping them gain access to the services they needed was meaningful to me. if you're lucky to have one of the good supervisors, your general day-to-day won't be terrible. the "take back time" policy is nice so you can go home early sometimes.
cons: terrible compensation. can't live off it in nyc. upper management does not care at all about staff. families complain all the time that they get a new case manager every month because staff isn't paid enough. it's sad but true. management knows this, they hear it all the time too but nothing ever changes. they don't reward hard work properly.

job_title: Full Time in New York, NY
pros: I worked there for couple of years.Both Directors are terrible, they love to micromanage people and they love to have written notes for everyone so later they can easly fire them. Its easy to get job there. Most of the people work there around year and leave beacuse of terrible managment situation. Everything what you can read on glassdoor about skip is true.
cons:
Only way to help this company is fire both directors
This company is non for profit organization, but only not for profit for regular employees,
whole director family is working there for great profit

job_title: Family Advisor in New York, NY
pros: Great opportunity to work in another area of social services, with flexibility and creativity if you are hired.
cons: Inconsistent management promoted confusion in work ethics and work environment. Unclean, cramped office environment.

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: You will get get experience and a lot of knowledge. Free health insurance. Families are great.
cons:
Micromanaged by non experienced first time supervisors. They might have knowledge of the job but not how to effectively manage staff. High turnover. Parents keep saying they can believe I'm still there.
No continuing education or training.

job_title: Case Manager in New York, NY
pros: You'll get some great entry-level experience in the social service/care coordination field. You'll also learn a lot about how the public sector functions. There is also free health/dental insurance for singles so that helps a lot.
cons: The compensation is very low, so be prepared for that. Especially living in NYC.

job_title: Care Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The owner is very Passionate about the work. She cares about the employees and she will back you if there’s ever a problem. The pay is alright and based on caseload and performance. Room for promotions
cons: The work gets tedious. If you enjoy doing the same thing over and over then its a good job.

job_title: Document Scanner Operation Assistant in Lumberton, NJ

cons: Walk from train station is far,  1/2 hour lunch break have to Gobble food down quick because if your outside you have to wait for slow elevator lol

job_title: LMSW in Rochester, NY
pros: You get entry level experience in case management

Pay is low, the cube walls are short so management can watch you, you have to fill out a sheet that states what you were doing for every 5 minute period of the day.  Intense pressure to bill.

cons: There is a maximum number of hours you can work per week (about 16) and the maximum number of hours you can work per day is four.

pros:
They will hire first time graduates. 


There is none
cons: They don't pay enough, when I first started working  at Skip it was hard work but you were not micromanage. It seems like when the HR and the

job_title: QA Auditor in New York, NY

cons: Not much money. Just the commute expense takes a toll out of small paycheck. Need to get more government funding!
